comments.commentBody:
With this kind of logic, it's evident that Trump will do nothing.
Because if there were any wiretaps, he would have already presented evidence to the public.
Once again, FAKE NEWS at its best.

Why does it matter to understand what went before?

Some parallels between George W. Bush in 2001 and Trump in 2017 : disdains and ignores work of the previous administration; believes own version of reality ("We make our own reality;" "alternative facts"); 'guided' by an opinionated member of the administration with his own agenda independent of events. A special and unique element: actively repudiates intelligence from all our agencies. Hello, next 9/11.

I sure wish The New York Times would not splash a headline like that on the front page.  Any time it is said that Trump "inherited" something negative from Obama, it strengthens Trump's and the GOP's newly discovered excuse and finger-pointing claim that Trump inherited a mess from Obama, allowing them to take no responsibility for future actions and events. There were many other ways to word this.
Your right luckygal, the NYT needs to do a better job of hiding the truth from us.
So you're saying that this problem just magically happened in the last week?
Yes, things were so much more acceptable when Obama was blaming anyone within 10 yards.  It was he who began using the term, "inherited".  Bush didn't whine like that.
This is where a cursory knowledge of World History would have come in handy for you -- Because then you would know that any problems with North Korea actually predate the Obama administration.

"He (Trump) could prepare for direct missile strikes on the launch sites, which Mr. Obama also considered, but there is little chance of hitting every target..." And if we launched a massive attack aimed to take out North Korea's nuclear weapons - even if we used conventional bombs - Kim Jong would then likely launch as many nukes as he could squeeze out - and with such a high failure rate of our ability to intercept incoming missiles, the likelihood of at least one of their nukes getting through is what, 50/50? If that happened we would then use our nukes at North Korea in minutes or seconds to prevent another US city or base from being destroyed with radiation wafting into China. Yikes.
Sounds logical. But we're not exactly dealing with logical on this side of the map.
He will impeach himself by not solving one single of all the complex things awaiting beiing solved.
If North Korea were geographically nearer to Israel, its nuclear sites would have been wiped out by now.

Thanks, MOL.

It was only your post that allowed me (finally) to parse ART I correctly.

This is just another example of how the "free market " doesn't work, and how business pushes to the lowest common denominator in order to make that profit even when it may violate ethics.  It is the how and why that regulation is imposed.  So much for the "free" market especially in "advanced" societies.

Beautiful story! I've been in similar circumstances. 15 yrs ago I was dx'ed with stage 3 colon cancer that metastasized to my liver a year later. Poor prognosis; I put my affairs in order. A concern was my 9 yr old son. I responded by arranging sports activities where he would have strong male mentors. I also reached out to male friends and relatives to play a role in his life as mentors. After my demise. Finally, I spent as much time with him as possible. The irony was that, although I had a ~40% chance to survive 5 years, I was well enough to ski and play hockey once recovered from treatment; we did these together often, skipping school / work on "snow days". Happy ending: despite the odds, I did not die – and my son grew up to be a wonderful adult, with whom I am still very close.

Fighting stage-4 incurable prostate cancer I find this piece extremely depressing. The thought of one's last cheeseburger, along with last steps and last time I get out of bed alive are the things that induce nightmares in me, driving me from my bed just to assure myself that stage of dying has yet to arrive. My cancer psychologist teaches me to concentrate on bringing happiness to every day.  I thought the writing would show me the sweeter side of that, but the wallowing in self-pity regarding last times and the end of future plans is banished any joy or comfort I thought I might find in this article.

Colonel Panic,

I wish for you JOY in every moment, absolutely understand the reference to self-pity. It is her best attempt to acknowledge the loneliness she feels through giving
her husband away while she is still alive. We are all afraid to die IMHO and perhaps
a contribution of Happiness will be forthcoming from how to enjoy life! May we all live in Love and support of each other. Smiles my friend : )

My wife Kathy died 16 months ago after 36+ years of being together.  I am not up to the accolades of Jason, nor was my late wife as published as Amy (although she left me with a manuscript for a children’s book and was a children's storyteller for 20+ years and a local "celebrity").  Kathy struggled through kidney cancer for 11+years with a level of warmth, love, music and humor that left an indelible mark on all that knew her.  She was a force, and it was my proud position to love her.  A few months before she died we were lying in bed together and she turned to me and proclaimed "I've decided who you should connect with after I die".  I have to admit that it was one of the most surprising conversations I have ever had, and one I was extremely uncomfortable having, or even listening to, and I shut it down quickly because I didn't want to even consider a time when Kathy would not be part of my life.  But that time did come, and I have come to regard it as one of the most loving acts of a wonderful partner, an act of incalculable generosity and selflessness.  Thank you Amy for the thoughtfulness you have shown both to Jason and to all of us.  As one who has been there, giving us, the survivors, the permission to move forward even as we will always grieve for our loss is an incredibly loving gift of infinite value.  Perhaps the fact that this article was sent to me by my (now) girlfriend, who claims she "jumped the line" of potential partners, is a testament to that generosity.

I met Amy when she came to our summer's writer's conference at Southampton College a few years back. I was a student volunteer, and my job was to pick up, and drop off, Amy at the airport, and serve as her driver/valet in-between. From the first, things were awkwardly funny. We couldn't find each other in the small Islip Airport. I had driven for a few famous authors, most were pleasant, but all had an aura of untouchability and aloofness. Not so with Amy. We hit it off immediately. She was funny, dear, and had just enough vulnerability to make me feel protective of her. She was nervous about speaking at our event, displaying that same fear many of us writers feel that we somehow sneaked into this fraternal order completely lacking the proper credentials, and we were bound to be found out--and soon. But Amy did her presentation, was bathed in love and admiration by all present, and took her success back to Chicago with her; back to the love of Jason and children. But before she left, she asked for my address so she could send me her book, "Encyclopedia of an Ordinary Life." Two weeks later, I received her book in the mail, inscribed in the sweetest script, "To Dennis, with buckets of good wishes." But the words that really stuck with me were written on the cover: "I have not survived against all odds. I have not lived to tell. I have not witnessed the extraordinary. This is my story." I dug that book out today, and I cried.

"This is highly reminiscent of events in my own family. When my mother was dying of cancer at age 44, she put together a list of eligible women for my father to consider as a future wife."

That's a little specific.

This article was so profound, that my wife and I decided to write the ad that we would've done if faced with this same situation. What a gift to us both to realize how grateful we are to have one another and to show a heightened sense of appreciation while we're still on the planet.

Thank you, Amy, for a lovely tribute to your husband. I am reminded of the day before my father died, of colon cancer at 49, when he insisted that my family take a long and windy drive, though, thin and weak, he could barely remain upright in the passenger seat. Our second stop was to the home of a long-time engineer friend, who, although not home at the time, was married to my mom within the year.

On April 8th, I am marrying your husband, except his name is John. He is the most exceptional man I have ever met, he makes me laugh, he taught me to dance, he has brought colors into my world I never knew I could see. His wife passed away 5 year ago after a very brief battle with cancer. Our daugher's go to school together. It was the night of the Winter Formal and my daughter asked if a new friend could come over to get ready, explaining she didn't know how to 'girl'. I met John that night. He was definitely not my type, tall and dorky, but kind, approachable. We saw more and more of each other as our children became closer.
We talk often about Karen. I know she did not want to leave and fought and raged against death just like I would. I am not a replacement. Our family has members here, now. We also have members who have passed to the other side. As I care for and love her children here, I picture her loving and caring for the two babies I miscarried. We are bound together by love in its purest form. I look forward to meeting her one day, having a glass of wine and laughing together about how John sucks at tieing Christmas trees to the roof of the car and the day I tired to teach her daughter to parallel park. I can't wait to hear how it looked from her vantage point.
I hope my story bring you some peace knowing that there is wine in heaven, but more importantly that love remains, continues, grows despite a change in location.

This is Amy Kraus Rosenthal.  Her writing looks for the meaning of life through personal thoughts and the pondering of the everyday. She turns the mundane into essentials, the trivial into necessities and most of all her curiosity into love. Now, she does so with such honesty it's beyond moving and I want to thank her for searching for the mysteries of life and trying to decipher them right here in our own laps.  Love to her family, Chicago and everyone that is lucky enough to be close to her. Read and buy her books for your children, for your friends and family and most of all for yourself.

Loved this puzzle! Enjoyed the plays on words, especially.

Today's Mini was harder!
I'm sorry that this is happening to the author but the manipulation and Facebook style invasion of privacy is off putting to say the least.
I agree RAC.

Some are lucky. Some wants more and still gets what he or she'd always wanted. A few will get to live "forever in happiness." For most, and it's a silent majority "most," true love is not a success story, but of happiness, of meaning, of "the Road Less Taken." The former (success) is defined as getting what you'd always wanted, and for love, to have it "forever." Yet, the most touching stories of true love is epitomized by this journey of Amy and Jason. 26 years has felt like "forever" in your heart, where time is not 24 hours, but each second with the person of affection felt like a nano-second and each nano-second without the each other felt like a decade. Happiness is defined as appreciating what you have and you certainly shared that with us. In the human kingdom, Love is more than just caring. The heart is able to leap beyond the realm of just "caring," which most animals automatically do for each other. The human heart can make sacrifices for the future of other loved ones, for we define love as how we vision it in the context of others. This is similar to Randy Pausch's "My Last Lecture," initially written to scribe a father's to-be-taught lessons of life for his children, to Steve Jobs' admission to Bill Gates that the computer they invented have not much improved education at his death bed (Bill's mother was a teacher), to the Love Story's famous line "Never Having to Say You're Sorry." It's not easy to say true love is about also letting the other person go.
The miracle is the love she has experienced. There are than medical miracles to be experienced in life.

Congrats that you have survived such a devastating diagnosis and prognosis. To tell  another person who doesn't share your fortune to "never give up" may seem encouraging, but those who have faced the demon cancer and are moving in from us need more than cheerleading. They need to hear that it's OK, that they will be remembered and honored, not for the length of time they fought cancer but for how they lived in spite of it.

I am 75 (he is 68) and often think about my husband and his life after me. I've told him about single women friends that might be a good partner for him. We talk about it, laugh, cry and hope it won't come too soon that one of us dies. My husband is a "Jason". This my 3rd marriage. I have been so fortunate.
